abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            methodologies are needed for addressing the problem of
            reconciling damage and needs assessments after a disaster,
            and tailoring project implementation to the refining of the
            needs estimate, such as by phasing construction and
            instituting checkpoints for incremental stages during
            implementation of construction components. A strong,
            experienced and independent Project Implementation Unit
            (PIU) familiar with Bank procedures is especially critical
            to effective implementation of fast-track emergency
            projects. Construction supervision by international
            consultants lent credibility to reconstruction
            activities-necessary in an environment of distrust of local
            code enforcement and construction quality. Activities that
            do not perform well in the early stages of the project, may
            perform very well later on, as demonstrated by the
            successful implementation of weather forecasting system. In
            order to guarantee the sustainability of the apartment
            blocks and its environment including the landscaping
            arrangements, site and block management organizations should
            be established. Specification and monitoring of the
            interfaces between different contractors and systems is
            essential. The maximum momentum in an emergency project is
            normally in the first few months after the disaster. The
            design of residential sites under emergency construction
            should recognize that the sites will become permanent
            settlements and allow for the long-term needs of
            beneficiaries in the broadest sense, and allow for the
            higher costs of such an approach. The Bank needs to develop
            appropriate, operationally-oriented protocols, procedures
            and design criteria for responding to situations demanding
            large emergency construction programs, that can be applied
            soon after a disaster to ensure that design meets the needs
            of long-term urban development, as well as the short-term
            emergency needs.
